trans-unit.source: Virtual Network VPN Gateway FAQ | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network VPN Gateway FAQ | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The VPN Gateway FAQ. FAQ for Microsoft Azure Virtual Network cross-premises connections, hybrid configuration connections, and VPN Gateways
trans-unit.target: The VPN Gateway FAQ. FAQ for Microsoft Azure Virtual Network cross-premises connections, hybrid configuration connections, and VPN Gateways

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: In fact, there is no region constraint.
trans-unit.target: In fact, there is no region constraint.

trans-unit.source: One virtual network can connect to another virtual network in the same region, or in a different Azure region.
trans-unit.target: One virtual network can connect to another virtual network in the same region, or in a different Azure region.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: You can connect to multiple sites by using Windows PowerShell and the Azure REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: You can connect to multiple sites by using Windows PowerShell and the Azure REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: See the <linkText>Multi-Site and VNet-to-VNet Connectivity</linkText><title></title> FAQ section.
trans-unit.target: See the <linkText>Multi-Site and VNet-to-VNet Connectivity</linkText><title></title> FAQ section.

trans-unit.source: The following cross-premises connections are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following cross-premises connections are supported:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Site-to-Site</linkText><title></title> – VPN connection over IPsec (IKE v1 and IKE v2).
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Site-to-Site</linkText><title></title> – VPN connection over IPsec (IKE v1 and IKE v2).

trans-unit.source: This type of connection requires a VPN device or RRAS.
trans-unit.target: This type of connection requires a VPN device or RRAS.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Point-to-Site</linkText><title></title> – VPN connection over SSTP (Secure Socket Tunneling Protocol).
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Point-to-Site</linkText><title></title> – VPN connection over SSTP (Secure Socket Tunneling Protocol).

trans-unit.source: This connection does not require a VPN device.
trans-unit.target: This connection does not require a VPN device.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet-to-VNet</linkText><title></title> - This type of connection is the same as a site-to-site configuration.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet-to-VNet</linkText><title></title> - This type of connection is the same as a site-to-site configuration.

trans-unit.source: VNet to VNet is a VPN connection over IPsec (IKE v1 and IKE v2).
trans-unit.target: VNet to VNet is a VPN connection over IPsec (IKE v1 and IKE v2).

trans-unit.source: It does not require a VPN device.
trans-unit.target: It does not require a VPN device.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Multi-Site</linkText><title></title> - This is a variation of a site-to-site configuration that allows you to connect multiple on-premises sites to a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Multi-Site</linkText><title></title> - This is a variation of a site-to-site configuration that allows you to connect multiple on-premises sites to a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ExpressRoute</linkText><title></title> - ExpressRoute is a direct connection to Azure from your WAN, not over the public Internet.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ExpressRoute</linkText><title></title> - ExpressRoute is a direct connection to Azure from your WAN, not over the public Internet.

trans-unit.source: See the <linkText>ExpressRoute Technical Overview</linkText><title></title> and the <linkText>ExpressRoute FAQ</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See the <linkText>ExpressRoute Technical Overview</linkText><title></title> and the <linkText>ExpressRoute FAQ</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Site-to-site connections let you connect between any of the computers located on your premises to any virtual machine or role instance within your virtual network, depending on how you choose to configure routing.
trans-unit.target: Site-to-site connections let you connect between any of the computers located on your premises to any virtual machine or role instance within your virtual network, depending on how you choose to configure routing.

trans-unit.source: It's a great option for an always-available cross-premises connection and is well-suited for hybrid configurations.
trans-unit.target: It's a great option for an always-available cross-premises connection and is well-suited for hybrid configurations.

trans-unit.source: This type of connection relies on an IPsec VPN appliance (hardware or soft appliance), which must be deployed at the edge of your network.
trans-unit.target: This type of connection relies on an IPsec VPN appliance (hardware or soft appliance), which must be deployed at the edge of your network.

trans-unit.source: In order to create this type of connection, you'll have to have the required VPN hardware and an externally facing IPv4 address.
trans-unit.target: In order to create this type of connection, you'll have to have the required VPN hardware and an externally facing IPv4 address.

trans-unit.source: Point-to-site connections let you connect from a single computer from anywhere to anything located in your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Point-to-site connections let you connect from a single computer from anywhere to anything located in your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: It uses the Windows in-box VPN client.
trans-unit.target: It uses the Windows in-box VPN client.

trans-unit.source: As part of the point-to-site configuration, you install a certificate and a VPN client configuration package, which contains the settings that allow your computer to connect to any virtual machine or role instance within the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: As part of the point-to-site configuration, you install a certificate and a VPN client configuration package, which contains the settings that allow your computer to connect to any virtual machine or role instance within the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: It's great when you want to connect to a virtual network, but aren't located on-premises.
trans-unit.target: It's great when you want to connect to a virtual network, but aren't located on-premises.

trans-unit.source: It's also a good option when you don't have access to VPN hardware or an externally facing IPv4 address, both of which are required for a site-to-site connection.
trans-unit.target: It's also a good option when you don't have access to VPN hardware or an externally facing IPv4 address, both of which are required for a site-to-site connection.

trans-unit.source: Note: You can configure your virtual network to use both site-to-site and point-to-site concurrently, provided that you create your site-to-site connection using a dynamic routing gateway.
trans-unit.target: Note: You can configure your virtual network to use both site-to-site and point-to-site concurrently, provided that you create your site-to-site connection using a dynamic routing gateway.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>About secure cross-premises connectivity for virtual networks</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>About secure cross-premises connectivity for virtual networks</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: ExpressRoute lets you create private connections between Microsoft datacenters and infrastructure that’s on your premises or in a co-location environment.
trans-unit.target: ExpressRoute lets you create private connections between Microsoft datacenters and infrastructure that’s on your premises or in a co-location environment.

trans-unit.source: With ExpressRoute, you can establish connections to Microsoft cloud services such as Microsoft Azure and Office 365 at an ExpressRoute partner co-location facility, or directly connect from your existing WAN network (such as a MPLS VPN provided by a network service provider).
trans-unit.target: With ExpressRoute, you can establish connections to Microsoft cloud services such as Microsoft Azure and Office 365 at an ExpressRoute partner co-location facility, or directly connect from your existing WAN network (such as a MPLS VPN provided by a network service provider).

trans-unit.source: ExpressRoute connections offer better security, more reliability, higher bandwidth, and lower latencies than typical connections over the Internet.
trans-unit.target: ExpressRoute connections offer better security, more reliability, higher bandwidth, and lower latencies than typical connections over the Internet.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, using ExpressRoute connections to transfer data between your on-premises network and Azure can also yield significant cost benefits.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, using ExpressRoute connections to transfer data between your on-premises network and Azure can also yield significant cost benefits.

trans-unit.source: If you already have created a cross-premises connection from your on-premises network to Azure, you can migrate to an ExpressRoute connection while keeping your virtual network intact.
trans-unit.target: If you already have created a cross-premises connection from your on-premises network to Azure, you can migrate to an ExpressRoute connection while keeping your virtual network intact.

trans-unit.source: See the <linkText>ExpressRoute FAQ</linkText><title></title> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See the <linkText>ExpressRoute FAQ</linkText><title></title> for more details.

trans-unit.source: We have validated a set of standard site-to-site VPN devices in partnership with device vendors.
trans-unit.target: We have validated a set of standard site-to-site VPN devices in partnership with device vendors.

trans-unit.source: A list of known compatible VPN devices, their corresponding configuration instructions or samples, and device specs can be found <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: A list of known compatible VPN devices, their corresponding configuration instructions or samples, and device specs can be found <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: All devices in the device families listed as known compatible should work with Virtual Network.
trans-unit.target: All devices in the device families listed as known compatible should work with Virtual Network.

trans-unit.source: To help configure your VPN device, refer to the device configuration sample or link that corresponds to appropriate device family.
trans-unit.target: To help configure your VPN device, refer to the device configuration sample or link that corresponds to appropriate device family.

trans-unit.source: If you do not see your device listed as a known compatible VPN device and want to use it for your VPN connection, you'll need to verify that it meets the supported IPsec/IKE configuration options and parameters listed <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not see your device listed as a known compatible VPN device and want to use it for your VPN connection, you'll need to verify that it meets the supported IPsec/IKE configuration options and parameters listed <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Devices meeting the minimum requirements should work well with VPN gateways.
trans-unit.target: Devices meeting the minimum requirements should work well with VPN gateways.

trans-unit.source: Please contact your device manufacturer for additional support and configuration instructions.
trans-unit.target: Please contact your device manufacturer for additional support and configuration instructions.

trans-unit.source: We support Windows Server 2012 Routing and Remote Access (RRAS) servers for site-to-site cross-premises configuration.
trans-unit.target: We support Windows Server 2012 Routing and Remote Access (RRAS) servers for site-to-site cross-premises configuration.

trans-unit.source: Other software VPN solutions should work with our gateway as long as they conform to industry standard IPsec implementations.
trans-unit.target: Other software VPN solutions should work with our gateway as long as they conform to industry standard IPsec implementations.

trans-unit.source: Contact the vendor of the software for configuration and support instructions.
trans-unit.target: Contact the vendor of the software for configuration and support instructions.

trans-unit.source: The following operating systems are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following operating systems are supported:

trans-unit.source: Windows 7 (64-bit version only)
trans-unit.target: Windows 7 (64-bit version only)

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2008 R2
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2008 R2

trans-unit.source: Windows 8 (64-bit version only)
trans-unit.target: Windows 8 (64-bit version only)

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Support is limited only to the Windows operating system versions listed above.
trans-unit.target: Support is limited only to the Windows operating system versions listed above.

trans-unit.source: We support up to 128 VPN clients to be able to connect to a virtual network at the same time.
trans-unit.target: We support up to 128 VPN clients to be able to connect to a virtual network at the same time.

trans-unit.source: At this time, only self-signed root certificates are supported.
trans-unit.target: At this time, only self-signed root certificates are supported.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: We use SSTP (Secure Socket Tunneling Protocol) to tunnel through firewalls.
trans-unit.target: We use SSTP (Secure Socket Tunneling Protocol) to tunnel through firewalls.

trans-unit.source: This tunnel will appear as an HTTPs connection.
trans-unit.target: This tunnel will appear as an HTTPs connection.

trans-unit.source: By default, the client computer will not reestablish the VPN connection automatically.
trans-unit.target: By default, the client computer will not reestablish the VPN connection automatically.

trans-unit.source: Auto-reconnect and DDNS are currently not supported in point-to-site VPNs.
trans-unit.target: Auto-reconnect and DDNS are currently not supported in point-to-site VPNs.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Both these solutions will work if you have a dynamic routing VPN gateway for your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Both these solutions will work if you have a dynamic routing VPN gateway for your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: We do not support point-to-site in static routing VPN gateways.
trans-unit.target: We do not support point-to-site in static routing VPN gateways.

trans-unit.source: Yes, it is possible.
trans-unit.target: Yes, it is possible.

trans-unit.source: But the virtual networks cannot have overlapping IP prefixes and the point-to-site address spaces must not overlap between the virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: But the virtual networks cannot have overlapping IP prefixes and the point-to-site address spaces must not overlap between the virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: It's difficult to maintain the exact throughput of the VPN tunnels.
trans-unit.target: It's difficult to maintain the exact throughput of the VPN tunnels.

trans-unit.source: IPsec and SSTP are crypto-heavy VPN protocols.
trans-unit.target: IPsec and SSTP are crypto-heavy VPN protocols.

trans-unit.source: Throughput is also limited by the latency and bandwidth between your premises and the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Throughput is also limited by the latency and bandwidth between your premises and the Internet.

trans-unit.source: Static routing gateways implement policy-based VPNs.
trans-unit.target: Static routing gateways implement policy-based VPNs.

trans-unit.source: Policy-based VPNs encrypt and direct packets through IPsec tunnels based on the combinations of address prefixes between your on premises network and the Azure VNet.
trans-unit.target: Policy-based VPNs encrypt and direct packets through IPsec tunnels based on the combinations of address prefixes between your on premises network and the Azure VNet.

trans-unit.source: The policy (or Traffic Selector) is usually defined as an access list in the VPN configuration.
trans-unit.target: The policy (or Traffic Selector) is usually defined as an access list in the VPN configuration.

trans-unit.source: Dynamic routing gateways implement the route-based VPNs.
trans-unit.target: Dynamic routing gateways implement the route-based VPNs.

trans-unit.source: Route-based VPNs use "routes" in the IP forwarding or routing table to direct packets into their corresponding tunnel interfaces.
trans-unit.target: Route-based VPNs use "routes" in the IP forwarding or routing table to direct packets into their corresponding tunnel interfaces.

trans-unit.source: The tunnel interfaces then encrypt or decrypt the packets in and out of the tunnels.
trans-unit.target: The tunnel interfaces then encrypt or decrypt the packets in and out of the tunnels.

trans-unit.source: The policy or traffic selector for route based VPNs are configured as any-to-any (or wild cards).
trans-unit.target: The policy or traffic selector for route based VPNs are configured as any-to-any (or wild cards).

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: You have to create your gateway first to get the IP address.
trans-unit.target: You have to create your gateway first to get the IP address.

trans-unit.source: The IP address will change if you delete and re-create your VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: The IP address will change if you delete and re-create your VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: Azure VPN uses PSK (Pre-Shared Key) authentication.
trans-unit.target: Azure VPN uses PSK (Pre-Shared Key) authentication.

trans-unit.source: We generate a pre-shared key (PSK) when we create the VPN tunnel.
trans-unit.target: We generate a pre-shared key (PSK) when we create the VPN tunnel.

trans-unit.source: You can change the auto-generated PSK to your own with the Set Pre-Shared Key PowerShell cmdlet or REST API.
trans-unit.target: You can change the auto-generated PSK to your own with the Set Pre-Shared Key PowerShell cmdlet or REST API.

trans-unit.source: Yes, the Set Pre-Shared Key API and PowerShell cmdlet can be used to configure both Azure static routing VPN and dynamic routing VPNs.
trans-unit.target: Yes, the Set Pre-Shared Key API and PowerShell cmdlet can be used to configure both Azure static routing VPN and dynamic routing VPNs.

trans-unit.source: We are limited to using pre-shared keys (PSK) for authentication.
trans-unit.target: We are limited to using pre-shared keys (PSK) for authentication.

trans-unit.source: We have a gateway service that we run to enable cross-premises connectivity.
trans-unit.target: We have a gateway service that we run to enable cross-premises connectivity.

trans-unit.source: We need 2 IP addresses from your routing domain for us to enable routing between your premises and the cloud.
trans-unit.target: We need 2 IP addresses from your routing domain for us to enable routing between your premises and the cloud.

trans-unit.source: We require you to specify at least a /29 subnet from which we can pick IP addresses for setting up routes.
trans-unit.target: We require you to specify at least a /29 subnet from which we can pick IP addresses for setting up routes.

trans-unit.source: Even though you can create a /29 subnet, understand that some features require a specific gateway size.
trans-unit.target: Even though you can create a /29 subnet, understand that some features require a specific gateway size.

trans-unit.source: Please follow the gateway subnet requirements for the feature you want to configure.
trans-unit.target: Please follow the gateway subnet requirements for the feature you want to configure.

trans-unit.source: Please note that you must not deploy virtual machines or role instances in the gateway subnet.
trans-unit.target: Please note that you must not deploy virtual machines or role instances in the gateway subnet.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the Azure Portal, add each range that you want sent through the gateway for your virtual network on the Networks page under Local Networks.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the Azure Portal, add each range that you want sent through the gateway for your virtual network on the Networks page under Local Networks.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Configure forced tunneling</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Configure forced tunneling</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Yes, you can deploy your own VPN gateways or servers in Azure either from the Azure Marketplace or creating your own VPN routers.
trans-unit.target: Yes, you can deploy your own VPN gateways or servers in Azure either from the Azure Marketplace or creating your own VPN routers.

trans-unit.source: You will need to configure User-Defined Routes in your virtual network to ensure traffic is routed properly between your on premises networks and your virtual network subnets.
trans-unit.target: You will need to configure User-Defined Routes in your virtual network to ensure traffic is routed properly between your on premises networks and your virtual network subnets.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>About VPN Gateways</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>About VPN Gateways</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Only the Dynamic Routing VPNs.
trans-unit.target: Only the Dynamic Routing VPNs.

trans-unit.source: No, both virtual networks MUST be using dynamic routing VPNs.
trans-unit.target: No, both virtual networks MUST be using dynamic routing VPNs.

trans-unit.source: Yes, it is protected by IPsec/IKE encryption.
trans-unit.target: Yes, it is protected by IPsec/IKE encryption.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Max.
trans-unit.target: Max.

trans-unit.source: 10 combined for the Basic and Standard Dynamic Routing gateways; 30 for the High Performance VPN gateways.
trans-unit.target: 10 combined for the Basic and Standard Dynamic Routing gateways; 30 for the High Performance VPN gateways.

trans-unit.source: Yes, point-to-site (P2S) VPNs can be used with the VPN gateways connecting to multiple on premises sites and other virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Yes, point-to-site (P2S) VPNs can be used with the VPN gateways connecting to multiple on premises sites and other virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: No, redundant tunnels between an Azure virtual network and an on-premises site is not supported.
trans-unit.target: No, redundant tunnels between an Azure virtual network and an on-premises site is not supported.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Overlapping address spaces will cause the netcfg file upload or Creating Virtual Network to fail.
trans-unit.target: Overlapping address spaces will cause the netcfg file upload or Creating Virtual Network to fail.

trans-unit.source: No, all VPN tunnels, including point-to-site VPNs, share the same Azure VPN gateway and the available bandwidth.
trans-unit.target: No, all VPN tunnels, including point-to-site VPNs, share the same Azure VPN gateway and the available bandwidth.

trans-unit.source: Transit traffic via Azure VPN gateway is possible, but rely on statically defined address spaces in the netcfg configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Transit traffic via Azure VPN gateway is possible, but rely on statically defined address spaces in the netcfg configuration file.

trans-unit.source: BGP is not yet supported with Azure Virtual Networks and VPN gateways.
trans-unit.target: BGP is not yet supported with Azure Virtual Networks and VPN gateways.

trans-unit.source: Without BGP, manually defining transit address spaces in netcfg is very error prone, and not recommended.
trans-unit.target: Without BGP, manually defining transit address spaces in netcfg is very error prone, and not recommended.

trans-unit.source: No, Azure by default generates different pre-shared keys for different VPN connections.
trans-unit.target: No, Azure by default generates different pre-shared keys for different VPN connections.

trans-unit.source: However, you can use the Set VPN Gateway Key REST API or PowerShell cmdlet to set the key value you prefer.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use the Set VPN Gateway Key REST API or PowerShell cmdlet to set the key value you prefer.

trans-unit.source: The key MUST be alphanumerical string of length between 1 to 128 characters.
trans-unit.target: The key MUST be alphanumerical string of length between 1 to 128 characters.

trans-unit.source: For traffic between different Azure virtual networks, Azure charges only for traffic traversing from one Azure region to another.
trans-unit.target: For traffic between different Azure virtual networks, Azure charges only for traffic traversing from one Azure region to another.

trans-unit.source: The charge rate is listed in the Azure <linkText>VPN Gateway Pricing</linkText><title></title> page.
trans-unit.target: The charge rate is listed in the Azure <linkText>VPN Gateway Pricing</linkText><title></title> page.

trans-unit.source: Yes, this is supported.
trans-unit.target: Yes, this is supported.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Configure ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections that coexist</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Configure ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections that coexist</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You have a few options.
trans-unit.target: You have a few options.

trans-unit.source: If you have RDP enabled and you have created an endpoint, you can connect to your virtual machine by using the VIP.
trans-unit.target: If you have RDP enabled and you have created an endpoint, you can connect to your virtual machine by using the VIP.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you would specify the VIP and the port that you want to connect to.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you would specify the VIP and the port that you want to connect to.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to configure the port on your virtual machine for the traffic.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to configure the port on your virtual machine for the traffic.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you would go to the Management Portal and save the settings for the RDP connection to your computer.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you would go to the Management Portal and save the settings for the RDP connection to your computer.

trans-unit.source: The settings will contain the necessary connection information.
trans-unit.target: The settings will contain the necessary connection information.

trans-unit.source: If you have a virtual network with cross-premises connectivity configured, you can connect to your virtual machine by using the internal DIP or private IP address.
trans-unit.target: If you have a virtual network with cross-premises connectivity configured, you can connect to your virtual machine by using the internal DIP or private IP address.

trans-unit.source: You can also connect to your virtual machine by internal DIP from another virtual machine that's located on the same virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You can also connect to your virtual machine by internal DIP from another virtual machine that's located on the same virtual network.

trans-unit.source: You can't RDP to your virtual machine by using the DIP if you are connecting from a location outside of your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You can't RDP to your virtual machine by using the DIP if you are connecting from a location outside of your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have a point-to-site virtual network configured and you don't establish a connection from your computer, you can't connect to the virtual machine by DIP.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have a point-to-site virtual network configured and you don't establish a connection from your computer, you can't connect to the virtual machine by DIP.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Only the traffic that has a destination IP that is contained in the virtual network Local Network IP address ranges that you specified will go through the virtual network gateway.
trans-unit.target: Only the traffic that has a destination IP that is contained in the virtual network Local Network IP address ranges that you specified will go through the virtual network gateway.

trans-unit.source: Traffic has a destination IP located within the virtual network will stay within the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Traffic has a destination IP located within the virtual network will stay within the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Other traffic is sent through the load balancer to the public networks, or if forced tunneling is used, sent through the Azure VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: Other traffic is sent through the load balancer to the public networks, or if forced tunneling is used, sent through the Azure VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: If you are troubleshooting, it's important to make sure that you have all the ranges listed in your Local Network that you want to send through the gateway.
trans-unit.target: If you are troubleshooting, it's important to make sure that you have all the ranges listed in your Local Network that you want to send through the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the Local Network address ranges do not overlap with any of the address ranges in the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the Local Network address ranges do not overlap with any of the address ranges in the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Also, you'll want to verify that the DNS server you are using is resolving the name to the proper IP address.
trans-unit.target: Also, you'll want to verify that the DNS server you are using is resolving the name to the proper IP address.

trans-unit.source: View more networking FAQs for additional details:
trans-unit.target: View more networking FAQs for additional details:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual Network FAQ</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual Network FAQ</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ExpressRoute FAQ</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ExpressRoute FAQ</linkText><title></title>
